questions.question_text: Which of the following can be used in the Debug Identification Section in Debug Mode for an infrastructure pattern? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Host Name / IP and PID will be used. So AC or CD would be answers.
AD is correct. Verified in Instance. Host Name / IP is required field.

questions.question_text: One method for deleting specific CIs not discovered in 30 days is:

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
NMAP (B) is the Answer
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/vancouver-it-operations-management/page/product/discovery/reference/credential-less-app-discovery.html

If the instance fails to identify a configuration item (CI) because of authentication failure, Discovery or Service Mapping can run selected Network Mapper (Nmap) commands with a MID Server to collect some basic information about the CI without using credentials.

From: https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/washingtondc-it-operations-management/page/product/discovery/concept/nmap-credential-less-discovery.html

Selected Answer: B
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/sandiego-it-operations-management/page/product/discovery/reference/credential-less-app-discovery.html

B - 
Nmap

questions.question_text: Which of the following choices must be installed on a MID Server to run Credential-less Discovery?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
What IP Service Affinity Does (per the documentation):

 “The IP service affinity functionality stores a mapping between an IP address, port, and the application service class that Discovery identified on that port.”

So:
 • It remembers what application (e.g., Apache, Oracle, Tomcat) was found running on a specific IP/port combo.
 • This helps ServiceNow optimize future discoveries of application services, not infrastructure.

Selected Answer: D
A system property called glide.discovery.ip_service_affinity allows Discovery to remember the last port of the IP address that was discovered. This property is set to false by default.

Selected Answer: D
Credential affinity has nothing to do with choosing the order of ports/services to probe.

Selected Answer: D
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/utah-it-operations-management/page/product/credentials/task/t_CheckIPServiceAffinity.html

Selected Answer: D
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/utah-it-operations-management/page/product/discovery/concept/c_GetStartedWithDiscovery.html#d142973e344

Selected Answer: D
I believe it is an IP Service Affinity, so I would say D

Selected Answer: D
D IS CORRECT
https://docs.servicenow.com/en-US/bundle/utah-it-operations-management/page/product/credentials/task/t_CheckIPServiceAffinity.html

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.

Selected Answer: D
D seems right

Probably D.
https://docs.servicenow.com/ja-JP/bundle/tokyo-it-operations-management/page/product/discovery/concept/c_GetStartedWithDiscovery.html

questions.question_text:
A network device has both an SSH port and an SNMP port open. Discovery tries the SSH probe first and it fails. This triggers the SNMP probe, which succeeds. Discovery uses SNMP first for subsequent discoveries on that device.
What discovery functionality allows the above to happen?
